title: Translation in the Hands of Many: Centering Lay Users in Machine Translation Interactions
author: Beatrice Savoldi (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), Alan Ramponi (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), Matteo Negri (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), Luisa Bentivogli (Fondazione Bruno Kessler), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses user-centered approaches and factors influencing user interactions with machine translation, which could inform techniques for enhancing the usability of audio-language interaction systems.
background: Understanding how non-expert users interact with machine translation tools and identifying factors such as usability, trust, and literacy that influence these interactions.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework for evaluating machine translation based on lay user experiences, focusing on usability, trust, and literacy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing studies on machine translation primarily emphasize model accuracy and performance metrics without considering user perspectives effectively.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work shifts the focus to how lay users engage with these technologies and highlights user-centered evaluation methods.

key_innovation: The unique focus on lay user interactions with machine translation tools offers insights for improving user experiences and aligning technology with real-world needs.
real_world_impact: The findings have the potential to enhance the accessibility and effectiveness of machine translation systems for broader audiences, including vulnerable populations.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.usability: **Usability** refers to the ease of use and user-friendliness of a system, emphasizing how well users can achieve their goals using that system.
new_terms.literacy: **Literacy** in this context refers to the knowledge and skills users possess to interact effectively with machine translation tools.
